cards.name: Sudden Reclamation
cards.text: Put the top four cards of your library into your graveyard, then return a creature card and a land card from your graveyard to your hand.
cards.flavor:
"There is no secret buried so deep that we will never find it."
—Kurtar, Sultai necromancer

rulings.text: You choose which creature card and land card to return to your hand as Sudden Reclamation resolves. This doesn't target either card.
If there are no land cards in your graveyard, you still choose a creature card to return, and vice versa.

cards.originalText: Put the top four cards of your library into your graveyard, then return a creature card and a land card from your graveyard to your hand.

cards.name: Temur Runemark
cards.text:
Enchant creature
Enchanted creature gets +2/+2.
Enchanted creature has trample as long as you control a blue or red permanent.
cards.originalText:
Enchant creature
Enchanted creature gets +2/+2.
Enchanted creature has trample as long as you control a blue or red permanent.

cards.name: Temur Sabertooth
cards.text: {1}{G}: You may return another creature you control to its owner's hand. If you do, Temur Sabertooth gains indestructible until end of turn.
cards.flavor: The Temur see themselves as a pack, their bonds more primal than the Abzan's.

rulings.text: You choose whether to return a creature and which creature to return as the activated ability resolves. This doesn't target any creature.

cards.originalText: {1}{G}: You may return another creature you control to its owner's hand. If you do, Temur Sabertooth gains indestructible until end of turn.

cards.name: Temur War Shaman
cards.text:
When Temur War Shaman enters the battlefield, manifest the top card of your library. (Put that card onto the battlefield face down as a 2/2 creature. Turn it face up any time for its mana cost if it's a creature card.)
Whenever a permanent you control is turned face up, if it's a creature, you may have it fight target creature you don't control.

rulings.text: The face-down permanent is a 2/2 creature with no name, mana cost, creature types, or abilities. It's colorless and has a converted mana cost of 0. Other effects that apply to the permanent can still grant or change any of these characteristics.

Any time you have priority, you may turn a manifested creature face up by revealing that it's a creature card (ignoring any copy effects or type-changing effects that might be applying to it) and paying its mana cost. This is a special action. It doesn't use the stack and can't be responded to.
If a manifested creature would have morph if it were face up, you may also turn it face up by paying its morph cost.
Unlike a face-down creature that was cast using the morph ability, a manifested creature may still be turned face up after it loses its abilities if it's a creature card.
Because the permanent is on the battlefield both before and after it's turned face up, turning a permanent face up doesn't cause any enters-the-battlefield abilities to trigger.
Because face-down creatures don't have names, they can't have the same name as any other creature, even another face-down creature.

A permanent that turns face up or face down changes characteristics but is otherwise the same permanent. Spells and abilities that were targeting that permanent, as well as Auras and Equipment that were attached to the permanent, aren't affected.
Turning a permanent face up or face down doesn't change whether that permanent is tapped or untapped.
At any time, you can look at a face-down permanent you control. You can't look at face-down permanents you don't control unless an effect allows you to or instructs you to.
If a face-down permanent you control leaves the battlefield, you must reveal it. You must also reveal all face-down spells and permanents you control if you leave the game or if the game ends.

You must ensure that your face-down spells and permanents can easily be differentiated from each other. You're not allowed to mix up the cards that represent them on the battlefield in order to confuse other players. The order they entered the battlefield should remain clear. Common methods for indicating this include using markers or dice, or simply placing them in order on the battlefield. You must also track how each became face down (manifested, cast face down using the morph ability, and so on).

There are no cards in the Fate Reforged set that would turn a face-down instant or sorcery card on the battlefield face up, but some older cards can try to do this. If something tries to turn a face-down instant or sorcery card on the battlefield face up, reveal that card to show all players it's an instant or sorcery card. The permanent remains on the battlefield face down. Abilities that trigger when a permanent turns face up won't trigger, because even though you revealed the card, it never turned face up.

Some older Magic sets feature double-faced cards, which have a Magic card face on each side rather than a Magic card face on one side and a Magic card back on the other. The rules for double-faced cards are changing slightly to account for the possibility that they are manifested. If a double-faced card is manifested, it will be put onto the battlefield face down. While face down, it can't transform. If the front face of the card is a creature card, you can turn it face up by paying its mana cost. If you do, its front face will be up. A double-faced permanent on the battlefield still can't be turned face down.

cards.originalText:
When Temur War Shaman enters the battlefield, manifest the top card of your library. (Put that card onto the battlefield face down as a 2/2 creature. Turn it face up any time for its mana cost if it's a creature card.)
Whenever a permanent you control is turned face up, if it's a creature, you may have it fight target creature you don't control.

cards.name: Warden of the First Tree
cards.text:
{1}{W/B}: Warden of the First Tree becomes a Human Warrior with base power and toughness 3/3.
{2}{W/B}{W/B}: If Warden of the First Tree is a Warrior, it becomes a Human Spirit Warrior with trample and lifelink.
{3}{W/B}{W/B}{W/B}: If Warden of the First Tree is a Spirit, put five +1/+1 counters on it.

rulings.text: Neither the first nor the second ability has a duration. If one of them resolves, it will remain in effect until Warden of the First Tree leaves the battlefield or some subsequent effect changes its characteristics.
The first and second activated abilities cause Warden of the First Tree to lose any other creature types it has. It retains any card types or supertypes it may have.

The first ability overwrites any previous effects that set the creature's base power and toughness to specific values. Any power- or toughness-setting effects that start to apply after the first ability resolves will overwrite this effect.

Effects that modify Warden of the First Tree's power or toughness, such as the one created by Titanic Growth, will apply to Warden of the First Tree no matter when they started to take effect. The same is true for any +1/+1 counters on Warden of the First Tree and effects that switch its power and toughness.

cards.originalText:
{1}{W/B}: Warden of the First Tree becomes a Human Warrior with base power and toughness 3/3.
{2}{W/B}{W/B}: If Warden of the First Tree is a Warrior, it becomes a Human Spirit Warrior with trample and lifelink.
{3}{W/B}{W/B}{W/B}: If Warden of the First Tree is a Spirit, put five +1/+1 counters on it.

cards.name: Whisperer of the Wilds
cards.text:
{T}: Add {G}.
Ferocious — {T}: Add {G}{G}. Activate this ability only if you control a creature with power 4 or greater.
cards.flavor: She speaks only in whispers but can be heard over the fiercest storm.
cards.originalText:
{T}: Add {G} to your mana pool.
Ferocious — {T}: Add {G}{G} to your mana pool. Activate this ability only if you control a creature with power 4 or greater.

cards.name: Whisperwood Elemental
cards.text:
At the beginning of your end step, manifest the top card of your library. (Put it onto the battlefield face down as a 2/2 creature. Turn it face up any time for its mana cost if it's a creature card.)
Sacrifice Whisperwood Elemental: Until end of turn, face-up nontoken creatures you control gain "When this creature dies, manifest the top card of your library."

rulings.text: The last ability grants that ability to face-up nontoken creatures you control as that ability resolves. Creatures that come under your control later in the turn won't have that ability.

The face-down permanent is a 2/2 creature with no name, mana cost, creature types, or abilities. It's colorless and has a converted mana cost of 0. Other effects that apply to the permanent can still grant or change any of these characteristics.

Any time you have priority, you may turn a manifested creature face up by revealing that it's a creature card (ignoring any copy effects or type-changing effects that might be applying to it) and paying its mana cost. This is a special action. It doesn't use the stack and can't be responded to.
If a manifested creature would have morph if it were face up, you may also turn it face up by paying its morph cost.
Unlike a face-down creature that was cast using the morph ability, a manifested creature may still be turned face up after it loses its abilities if it's a creature card.
Because the permanent is on the battlefield both before and after it's turned face up, turning a permanent face up doesn't cause any enters-the-battlefield abilities to trigger.

Turning a permanent face up or face down doesn't change whether that permanent is tapped or untapped.
At any time, you can look at a face-down permanent you control. You can't look at face-down permanents you don't control unless an effect allows you to or instructs you to.
If a face-down permanent you control leaves the battlefield, you must reveal it. You must also reveal all face-down spells and permanents you control if you leave the game or if the game ends.

You must ensure that your face-down spells and permanents can easily be differentiated from each other. You're not allowed to mix up the cards that represent them on the battlefield in order to confuse other players. The order they entered the battlefield should remain clear. Common methods for indicating this include using markers or dice, or simply placing them in order on the battlefield. You must also track how each became face down (manifested, cast face down using the morph ability, and so on).

There are no cards in the Fate Reforged set that would turn a face-down instant or sorcery card on the battlefield face up, but some older cards can try to do this. If something tries to turn a face-down instant or sorcery card on the battlefield face up, reveal that card to show all players it's an instant or sorcery card. The permanent remains on the battlefield face down. Abilities that trigger when a permanent turns face up won't trigger, because even though you revealed the card, it never turned face up.

Some older Magic sets feature double-faced cards, which have a Magic card face on each side rather than a Magic card face on one side and a Magic card back on the other. The rules for double-faced cards are changing slightly to account for the possibility that they are manifested. If a double-faced card is manifested, it will be put onto the battlefield face down. While face down, it can't transform. If the front face of the card is a creature card, you can turn it face up by paying its mana cost. If you do, its front face will be up. A double-faced permanent on the battlefield still can't be turned face down.

cards.originalText:
At the beginning of your end step, manifest the top card of your library. (Put it onto the battlefield face down as a 2/2 creature. Turn it face up any time for its mana cost if it's a creature card.)
Sacrifice Whisperwood Elemental: Until end of turn, face-up nontoken creatures you control gain "When this creature dies, manifest the top card of your library."

cards.name: Wildcall
cards.text: Manifest the top card of your library, then put X +1/+1 counters on it. (To manifest a card, put it onto the battlefield face down as a 2/2 creature. Turn it face up any time for its mana cost if it's a creature card.)
cards.flavor: A howl on the wind hides many dangers.

rulings.text: If you choose 0 for X, you'll just manifest the top card of your library.

cards.originalText: Manifest the top card of your library, then put X +1/+1 counters on it. (To manifest a card, put it onto the battlefield face down as a 2/2 creature. Turn it face up any time for its mana cost if it's a creature card.)

cards.name: Winds of Qal Sisma
cards.text:
Prevent all combat damage that would be dealt this turn.
Ferocious — If you control a creature with power 4 or greater, instead prevent all combat damage that would be dealt this turn by creatures your opponents control.

rulings.text: If you control a creature with power 4 or greater as Winds of Qal Sisma resolves, the ferocious ability will apply. Combat damage dealt by creatures your opponents control will be prevented, even if you no longer control a creature with power 4 or greater as that damage would be dealt.

cards.originalText:
Prevent all combat damage that would be dealt this turn.
Ferocious — If you control a creature with power 4 or greater, instead prevent all combat damage that would be dealt this turn by creatures your opponents control.

cards.name: Yasova Dragonclaw
cards.text:
Trample
At the beginning of combat on your turn, you may pay {1}{U/R}{U/R}. If you do, gain control of target creature an opponent controls with power less than Yasova Dragonclaw's power until end of turn, untap that creature, and it gains haste until end of turn.

rulings.text: The powers of the target creature and Yasova Dragonclaw are checked as you put the ability on the stack and again as the ability resolves. Once the ability resolves, it doesn't matter what happens to either creature's power.
Gaining control of a creature doesn't cause you to gain control of any Auras or Equipment attached to it.

cards.originalText:
Trample
At the beginning of combat on your turn, you may pay {1}{U/R}{U/R}. If you do, gain control of target creature an opponent controls with power less than Yasova Dragonclaw's power until end of turn, untap that creature, and it gains haste until end of turn.

cards.name: Atarka, World Render
cards.text:
Flying, trample
Whenever a Dragon you control attacks, it gains double strike until end of turn.
cards.flavor:
"Her hunger knows no limit. Left unchecked, she would feast on all of Tarkir."
—Yasova Dragonclaw

foreignNames.name: 世界を溶かすもの、アタルカ

cards.originalText:
Flying, trample
Whenever a Dragon you control attacks, it gains double strike until end of turn.

cards.name: Cunning Strike
cards.text:
Cunning Strike deals 2 damage to target creature and 2 damage to target player or planeswalker.
Draw a card.
cards.flavor:
"The opponent who blocks the path, becomes the path."
—Shu Yun, the Silent Tempest

rulings.text: You can't cast Cunning Strike unless you target both a creature and a player. If one target (but not both) is illegal as Cunning Strike resolves, it deals damage to the remaining legal target and you draw a card. If both targets are illegal, the spell won't resolve and none of its effects will happen. You won't draw a card in that case.

cards.originalText:
Cunning Strike deals 2 damage to target creature and 2 damage to target player.
Draw a card.

cards.name: Dromoka, the Eternal
cards.text:
Flying
Whenever a Dragon you control attacks, bolster 2. (Choose a creature with the least toughness among creatures you control and put two +1/+1 counters on it.)
cards.flavor:
"The bane of countless shattered weapons, each a failure to slay her."
—Daghatar the Adamant

rulings.text: Each Dragon you attack with will cause Dromoka's triggered ability to trigger. For each instance of the ability, you'll determine which creature to put +1/+1 counters on as it resolves. Specifically, the creature you control with the lowest toughness as the first such ability resolves may not have the lowest toughness as the second such ability resolves.

Bolster itself doesn't target any creature, though some spells and abilities that bolster may have other effects that target creatures. For example, you could put counters on a creature with protection from white with Abzan Skycaptain's bolster ability.
You determine which creature to put counters on as the spell or ability that instructs you to bolster resolves.

cards.originalText:
Flying
Whenever a Dragon you control attacks, bolster 2. (Choose a creature with the least toughness among creatures you control and put two +1/+1 counters on it.)

cards.name: Ethereal Ambush
cards.text: Manifest the top two cards of your library. (To manifest a card, put it onto the battlefield face down as a 2/2 creature. Turn it face up any time for its mana cost if it's a creature card.)
cards.flavor: The energies of the Temur lands are readily unleashed upon intruders.

rulings.text: The cards are manifested one at a time. It must remain clear which face-down creature was the top card of your library and which one was the second card of your library.

If you're playing with the top card of your library revealed as Ethereal Ambush resolves (perhaps because you control a card such as Courser of Kruphix), you'll manifest the top card, reveal the next card (now the top card), and then manifest that card.

The face-down permanent is a 2/2 creature with no name, mana cost, creature types, or abilities. It's colorless and has a converted mana cost of 0. Other effects that apply to the permanent can still grant or change any of these characteristics.

Any time you have priority, you may turn a manifested creature face up by revealing that it's a creature card (ignoring any copy effects or type-changing effects that might be applying to it) and paying its mana cost. This is a special action. It doesn't use the stack and can't be responded to.

Common methods for indicating this include using markers or dice, or simply placing them in order on the battlefield. You must also track how each became face down (manifested, cast face down using the morph ability, and so on).

There are no cards in the Fate Reforged set that would turn a face-down instant or sorcery card on the battlefield face up, but some older cards can try to do this. If something tries to turn a face-down instant or sorcery card on the battlefield face up, reveal that card to show all players it's an instant or sorcery card. The permanent remains on the battlefield face down. Abilities that trigger when a permanent turns face up won't trigger, because even though you revealed the card, it never turned face up.

Some older Magic sets feature double-faced cards, which have a Magic card face on each side rather than a Magic card face on one side and a Magic card back on the other. The rules for double-faced cards are changing slightly to account for the possibility that they are manifested. If a double-faced card is manifested, it will be put onto the battlefield face down. While face down, it can't transform. If the front face of the card is a creature card, you can turn it face up by paying its mana cost. If you do, its front face will be up. A double-faced permanent on the battlefield still can't be turned face down.

cards.originalText: Manifest the top two cards of your library. (To manifest a card, put it onto the battlefield face down as a 2/2 creature. Turn it face up any time for its mana cost if it's a creature card.)

cards.name: Grim Contest
cards.text: Choose target creature you control and target creature an opponent controls. Each of those creatures deals damage equal to its toughness to the other.
cards.flavor: The invader hoped he could survive the beast's jaws and emerge through its rotting skin.

rulings.text: If either target is an illegal target as Grim Contest tries to resolve, neither creature will deal or be dealt damage.

cards.originalText: Choose target creature you control and target creature an opponent controls. Each of those creatures deals damage equal to its toughness to the other.

cards.name: Harsh Sustenance
cards.text: Harsh Sustenance deals X damage to any target and you gain X life, where X is the number of creatures you control.
cards.flavor: The Shifting Wastes provide refuge to those who know where to look for it.
cards.originalText: Harsh Sustenance deals X damage to target creature or player and you gain X life, where X is the number of creatures you control.

cards.name: Kolaghan, the Storm's Fury
cards.text:
Flying
Whenever a Dragon you control attacks, creatures you control get +1/+0 until end of turn.
Dash {3}{B}{R} (You may cast this spell for its dash cost. If you do, it gains haste, and it's returned from the battlefield to its owner's hand at the beginning of the next end step.)

rulings.text: If you choose to pay the dash cost rather than the mana cost, you're still casting the spell. It goes on the stack and can be responded to and countered. You can cast a creature spell for its dash cost only when you otherwise could cast that creature spell. Most of the time, this means during your main phase when the stack is empty.

If you pay the dash cost to cast a creature spell, that card will be returned to its owner's hand only if it's still on the battlefield when its triggered ability resolves. If it dies or goes to another zone before then, it will stay where it is.
You don't have to attack with the creature with dash unless another ability says you do.
If a creature enters the battlefield as a copy of or becomes a copy of a creature whose dash cost was paid, the copy won't have haste and won't be returned to its owner's hand.

foreignNames.name: Kólagan, la Furia de la Tormenta

cards.originalText:
Flying
Whenever a Dragon you control attacks, creatures you control get +1/+0 until end of turn.
Dash {3}{B}{R} (You may cast this spell for its dash cost. If you do, it gains haste, and it's returned from the battlefield to its owner's hand at the beginning of the next end step.)

cards.name: Ojutai, Soul of Winter
cards.text:
Flying, vigilance
Whenever a Dragon you control attacks, tap target nonland permanent an opponent controls. That permanent doesn't untap during its controller's next untap step.
cards.flavor:
"When I battled Ojutai, I realized my learning had only begun."
—Shu Yun, the Silent Tempest

rulings.text: The triggered ability can target a nonland permanent that's already tapped. That permanent won't untap during its controller's next untap step.

The ability tracks the permanent, but not its controller. If the permanent changes controllers before its first controller's next untap step, then it won't untap during its new controller's next untap step.

The ability only applies during the controller's next untap step, even if the permanent has been the target of Ojutai's triggered ability more than once. The permanent won't stay tapped through multiple untap steps.

cards.originalText:
Flying, vigilance
Whenever a Dragon you control attacks, tap target nonland permanent an opponent controls. That permanent doesn't untap during its controller's next untap step.

cards.name: Silumgar, the Drifting Death
cards.text:
Flying, hexproof
Whenever a Dragon you control attacks, creatures defending player controls get -1/-1 until end of turn.
cards.flavor:
"No machinations, no puppet strings, no plots. Just pure, sweeping death."
—Tasigur, the Golden Fang

rulings.text: The creatures affected by Silumgar's triggered ability are determined relative to the Dragon that attacked. For example, if Silumgar attacked one opponent and two other Dragons attacked another opponent, creatures controlled by the first opponent would get -1/-1 until end of turn and creatures controlled by the second opponent would get -2/-2 until end of turn.

cards.originalText:
Flying, hexproof
Whenever a Dragon you control attacks, creatures defending player controls get -1/-1 until end of turn.

cards.name: War Flare
cards.text: Creatures you control get +2/+1 until end of turn. Untap those creatures.
cards.flavor:
"No sun or fire can warm my blood quite like a war flare."
—Urut Barzeel, Mardu hordechief
cards.originalText: Creatures you control get +2/+1 until end of turn. Untap those creatures.

cards.name: Goblin Boom Keg
cards.text:
At the beginning of your upkeep, sacrifice Goblin Boom Keg.
When Goblin Boom Keg is put into a graveyard from the battlefield, it deals 3 damage to any target.
cards.flavor: Dragonfire spawned many imitations. Some were more dramatic than others.
cards.originalText:
At the beginning of your upkeep, sacrifice Goblin Boom Keg.
When Goblin Boom Keg is put into a graveyard from the battlefield, it deals 3 damage to target creature or player.

cards.name: Hero's Blade
cards.flavor: The best swords are forged with dragonfire.

rulings.text: The triggered ability will trigger when one of the Gods from Theros block enters the battlefield only if your devotion is high enough that it's a creature when it enters. If Hero's Blade is attached to a God that stops being a creature (or any creature that stops being a creature), it will become unattached.

cards.name: Hewed Stone Retainers
cards.text: Cast this spell only if you've cast another spell this turn.
cards.flavor:
"Their origins are shrouded in mystery. I believe they are the protectors of the lost secrets of our world."
—Jilaya, Temur whisperer

rulings.text: It doesn't matter whether the other spell resolved. It could have been countered or, if you've somehow cast Hewed Stone Retainers as though it had flash, it could still be on the stack.

cards.originalText: Cast Hewed Stone Retainers only if you've cast another spell this turn.

cards.name: Pilgrim of the Fires
cards.text: First strike, trample
cards.flavor: The most skilled Jeskai artisans can craft imposing golems with such precision that they will last an eternity—the time believed necessary to master the Fires of the Jeskai Way.
cards.originalText: First strike, trample

cards.name: Scroll of the Masters
cards.text:
Whenever you cast a noncreature spell, put a lore counter on Scroll of the Masters.
{3}, {T}: Target creature you control gets +1/+1 until end of turn for each lore counter on Scroll of the Masters.

rulings.text: Count the number of lore counters on Scroll of the Masters as the activated ability resolves to determine how big a bonus the target creature gets. If Scroll of the Masters isn't on the battlefield at that time, use the number of lore counters on it when it left the battlefield.
Once the activated ability has resolved, changing the number of lore counters on Scroll of the Masters won't affect the bonus that activation granted.

cards.originalText:
Whenever you cast a noncreature spell, put a lore counter on Scroll of the Masters.
{3}, {T}: Target creature you control gets +1/+1 until end of turn for each lore counter on Scroll of the Masters.

cards.name: Ugin's Construct
cards.text: When Ugin's Construct enters the battlefield, sacrifice a permanent that's one or more colors.
cards.flavor: While trapping the Eldrazi on Zendikar, Ugin learned little from Sorin, but he gleaned the rudiments of lithomancy from Nahiri.

rulings.text: If you control only colorless permanents as the ability resolves (for example, basic lands and face-down permanents), you won't sacrifice anything.

cards.originalText: When Ugin's Construct enters the battlefield, sacrifice a permanent that's one or more colors.

{T}: Add {B} or {R}.

cards.name: Crucible of the Spirit Dragon
cards.text:
{T}: Add {C}.
{1}, {T}: Put a storage counter on Crucible of the Spirit Dragon.
{T}, Remove X storage counters from Crucible of the Spirit Dragon: Add X mana in any combination of colors. Spend this mana only to cast Dragon spells or activate abilities of Dragons.

rulings.text: You can use mana generated by the last ability to pay an alternative cost (such as a dash cost) or an additional cost to cast a Dragon spell. It's not limited to paying just that spell's mana cost.
An activated ability appears in the form "Cost: Effect."

Notably, turning a face-down creature face up isn't an activated ability. If you manifest a Dragon creature card or cast a Dragon creature card face down using the morph ability, you can't use mana generated by the last ability to turn that card face up.
The mana generated by the last ability can't be spent to activate abilities of Dragon sources that aren't on the battlefield.

cards.originalText:
{T}: Add {1} to your mana pool.
{1}, {T}: Put a storage counter on Crucible of the Spirit Dragon.
{T}, Remove X storage counters from Crucible of the Spirit Dragon: Add X mana in any combination of colors to your mana pool. Spend this mana only to cast Dragon spells or activate abilities of Dragons.

cards.name: Aeolipile
cards.text: {1}, {T}, Sacrifice Aeolipile: It deals 2 damage to any target.
cards.flavor:
"Although fragile, the Aeolipile could be quite destructive."
—Sarpadian Empires, vol. I
cards.originalText: {1}, {T}: Sacrifice Aeolipile to have it deal 2 damage to any target.

cards.name: Balm of Restoration
cards.text:
{1}, {T}, Sacrifice Balm of Restoration: Choose one —
• You gain 2 life.
• Prevent the next 2 damage that would be dealt to any target this turn.
cards.flavor:
"Not all armies enjoyed the services of a medic. For them, Balm of Restoration was that much more valuable."
—Sarpadian Empires, vol. I
cards.originalText: {1}, {T}: Sacrifice Balm of Restoration to gain 2 life or prevent up to 2 damage to any player or creature.

cards.name: Conch Horn
cards.text: {1}, {T}, Sacrifice Conch Horn: Draw two cards, then put a card from your hand on top of your library.
cards.flavor: Even the most skilled of modern mages only partially understand the Conch Horn's awesome powers.

rulings.text: You draw two cards, then put one back as part of the same effect. You can't do anything in between. Anything that triggers off of card drawing will wait until you finish resolving this ability before going on the stack.

cards.originalText: {1}, {T}: Sacrifice Conch Horn. Draw two cards, then put any one card from your hand back on top of your library.

cards.name: Delif's Cone
cards.text: {T}, Sacrifice Delif's Cone: This turn, when target creature you control attacks and isn't blocked, you may gain life equal to its power. If you do, it assigns no combat damage this turn.
cards.flavor: "Where is it written that beasts must cause pain?" —Delif, Ponderings

rulings.text: If you use the ability after blockers are declared, it won't trigger at all. So you want to use it before blockers are declared.
This card has an activated ability that creates a triggered ability which watches the target creature.

An ability that triggers when something "attacks and isn't blocked" triggers in the declare blockers step after blockers are declared if (1) that creature is attacking and (2) no creatures are declared to block it. It will trigger even if that creature was put onto the battlefield attacking rather than having been declared as an attacker in the declare attackers step.

cards.originalText: {T}: Sacrifice Delif's Cone. If target creature you control attacks and is not blocked, you may choose to gain its power in life. If you do so, it deals no damage to opponent this turn.

cards.name: Delif's Cube
cards.text:
{2}, {T}: This turn, when target creature you control attacks and isn't blocked, it assigns no combat damage this turn and you put a cube counter on Delif's Cube.
{2}, Remove a cube counter from Delif's Cube: Regenerate target creature.

rulings.text: If you use the ability after blockers are declared, it won't trigger at all. So you want to use it before blockers are declared.
This card has an activated ability that creates a triggered ability which watches the target creature.

An ability that triggers when something "attacks and isn't blocked" triggers in the declare blockers step after blockers are declared if (1) that creature is attacking and (2) no creatures are declared to block it. It will trigger even if that creature was put onto the battlefield attacking rather than having been declared as an attacker in the declare attackers step.

cards.originalText:
{2}, {T}: If target creature you control attacks and is not blocked, it deals no damage to opponent. Instead, put a cube counter on Delif's Cube.
{2}: Remove a cube counter to regenerate a target creature.

cards.name: Draconian Cylix
cards.text: {2}, {T}, Discard a card at random: Regenerate target creature.
cards.flavor:
"There is no gain without sacrifice."
—Icatian proverb

rulings.text: The card is discarded from your hand during announcement and as a cost.

cards.originalText: {2}, {T}: Discard a card at random from your hand to regenerate a target creature.

cards.name: Elven Lyre
cards.text: {1}, {T}, Sacrifice Elven Lyre: Target creature gets +2/+2 until end of turn.
cards.flavor: Scholars are uncertain whether it was the actual sound or some other magical property of the Elven Lyre that transformed its player.
cards.originalText: {1}, {T}: Sacrifice Elven Lyre to give a target creature +2/+2 until end of turn.

cards.name: Implements of Sacrifice
cards.text: {1}, {T}, Sacrifice Implements of Sacrifice: Add two mana of any one color.
cards.flavor: Relics of the Order of the Ebon Hand, the bowl and dagger bespeak the hideous cruelty of its rituals.
cards.originalText: {1}, {T}: Sacrifice Implements of Sacrifice to add 2 mana of any one color to your mana pool. Play this ability as an interrupt.

cards.name: Ring of Renewal
cards.text: {5}, {T}: Discard a card at random, then draw two cards.
cards.flavor: To the uninitiated, the Ring of Renewal is merely an oddity. For those fluent in the wielding of magic, however, it is a source of great knowledge.
cards.originalText: {5}, {T}: Discard a card at random from your hand and draw two cards.

cards.name: Spirit Shield
cards.text:
You may choose not to untap Spirit Shield during your untap step.
{2}, {T}: Target creature gets +0/+2 for as long as Spirit Shield remains tapped.
cards.flavor: At times, survival must outweigh all other considerations.
cards.originalText:
{2}, {T}: Target creature gets +0/+2 as long as Spirit Shield remains tapped.
You may choose not to untap Spirit Shield as normal during your untap phase.

cards.name: Zelyon Sword
cards.text:
You may choose not to untap Zelyon Sword during your untap step.
{3}, {T}: Target creature gets +2/+0 for as long as Zelyon Sword remains tapped.
cards.flavor: No sheath shall hold what finds its home in flesh.
cards.originalText:
{3}, {T}: Target creature gets +2/+0 as long as Zelyon Sword remains tapped.
You may choose not to untap Zelyon Sword as normal during your untap phase.

cards.name: Armor Thrull
cards.text: {T}, Sacrifice Armor Thrull: Put a +1/+2 counter on target creature.
cards.flavor:
"Except for a bare spot at the base of their skulls, Armor Thrulls bear interlocking plates and spikes with the strength of steel. Their design is almost artistic."
—Endrek Sahr, "Thrulls"
cards.originalText: {T}: Sacrifice Armor Thrull to put a +1/+2 counter on a target creature.

cards.name: Armor Thrull
cards.text: {T}, Sacrifice Armor Thrull: Put a +1/+2 counter on target creature.
cards.flavor: Occasionally, an ally balked at wearing a dead Thrull as armor. The priests' whips, however, were usually enough to encourage a more practical outlook.
cards.originalText: {T}: Sacrifice Armor Thrull to put a +1/+2 counter on a target creature.

cards.name: Armor Thrull
cards.text: {T}, Sacrifice Armor Thrull: Put a +1/+2 counter on target creature.
cards.flavor:
"They gave their lives to strengthen the Order's armies, until they declined this honor in favor of joining the Thrull Rebellion."
—Jherana Rure, Counter-Insurgency Commander
cards.originalText: {T}: Sacrifice Armor Thrull to put a +1/+2 counter on a target creature.

cards.name: Armor Thrull
cards.text: {T}, Sacrifice Armor Thrull: Put a +1/+2 counter on target creature.
cards.flavor:
"The worst thing about being a mercenary for the Ebon Hand is having to wear a dead Thrull."
—Ivra Jursdotter
cards.originalText: {T}: Sacrifice Armor Thrull to put a +1/+2 counter on a target creature.

cards.name: Basal Thrull
cards.text: {T}, Sacrifice Basal Thrull: Add {B}{B}.
cards.flavor:
Initially bred for sacrifice, the Thrulls eventually turned on their masters, the Order of the Ebon Hand, with gruesome results.
—Sarpadian Empires, vol. II
cards.originalText: {T}: Sacrifice Basal Thrull to add {B}{B} to your mana pool. Play this ability as an interrupt.

cards.name: Basal Thrull
cards.text: {T}, Sacrifice Basal Thrull: Add {B}{B}.
cards.flavor:
"To create the first Thrulls, I only introduced alchemic elements into the Order's necromancy; Tourach's principles remained unchanged."
—Endrek Sahr, Master Breeder
cards.originalText: {T}: Sacrifice Basal Thrull to add {B}{B} to your mana pool. Play this ability as an interrupt.

cards.name: Basal Thrull
cards.text: {T}, Sacrifice Basal Thrull: Add {B}{B}.
cards.flavor:
Although my later designs were much more sophisticated, Basal Thrulls were no less a success."
—Endrek Sahr, "Thrulls"
cards.originalText: {T}: Sacrifice Basal Thrull to add {B}{B} to your mana pool. Play this ability as an interrupt.

cards.name: Basal Thrull
cards.text: {T}, Sacrifice Basal Thrull: Add {B}{B}.
cards.flavor:
"Above all, a well crafted Thrull should be hideous—blasted of countenance and twisted of limb—to inspire fear and revulsion."
—Endrek Sahr, Master Breeder
cards.originalText: {T}: Sacrifice Basal Thrull to add {B}{B} to your mana pool. Play this ability as an interrupt.

cards.name: Breeding Pit
cards.text:
At the beginning of your upkeep, sacrifice Breeding Pit unless you pay {B}{B}.
At the beginning of your end step, create a 0/1 black Thrull creature token.
cards.flavor: The Thrulls bred at a terrifying pace. In the end, they overwhelmed the Order of the Ebon Hand.

rulings.text: Breeding Pit must actually be on the battlefield at the beginning of the endstep in order for you to get a Thrull. The getting of the Thrull is not part of paying the upkeep, it is part of having the card on the battlefield.

cards.originalText: During your upkeep, pay {B}{B} or bury Breeding Pit. At the end of your turn, put a Thrull token into play. Treat this token as a 0/1 black creature.

cards.name: Derelor
cards.text: Black spells you cast cost {B} more to cast.
cards.flavor:
"Strength it has, but at the cost of a continuous supply of energy. Such failure can bear only one result."
—From the execution order for Endrek Sahr, Master Breeder
cards.originalText: Your black spells cost an additional {B} to cast.

cards.name: Ebon Praetor
cards.text:
First strike, trample
At the beginning of your upkeep, put a -2/-2 counter on Ebon Praetor.
Sacrifice a creature: Remove a -2/-2 counter from Ebon Praetor. If the sacrificed creature was a Thrull, put a +1/+0 counter on Ebon Praetor. Activate this ability only during your upkeep and only once each turn.
cards.originalText:
Trample, first strike
During your upkeep, put a -2/-2 counter on Ebon Praetor.
You may sacrifice a creature during your upkeep to remove a -2/-2 counter from Ebon Praetor. If the creature sacrificed was a Thrull, also put a +1/+0 counter on Ebon Praetor. Only one creature may be sacrificed in this manner each turn.

cards.name: Hymn to Tourach
cards.text: Target player discards two cards at random.
cards.flavor:
"Tourach's power was such that his followers deified him after his death."
—Sarpadian Empires, vol. II
cards.originalText: Target player discards two cards at random from his or her hand. If target player does not have enough cards, his or her entire hand is discarded.

cards.name: Hymn to Tourach
cards.text: Target player discards two cards at random.
cards.flavor:
"The eerie, wailing Hymn caused insanity even in hardened warriors."
—Sarpadian Empires, vol. II
cards.originalText: Target player discards two cards at random from his or her hand. If target player does not have enough cards, his or her entire hand is discarded.

cards.name: Hymn to Tourach
cards.text: Target player discards two cards at random.
cards.flavor: Knowing the Hymn's power, the followers of Leitbur carefully guarded their pillaged transcriptions.
cards.originalText: Target player discards two cards at random from his or her hand. If target player does not have enough cards, his or her entire hand is discarded.

cards.name: Hymn to Tourach
cards.text: Target player discards two cards at random.
cards.flavor: Members of the Order often played the Hymn on instruments made from their victims' bones.
cards.originalText: Target player discards two cards at random from his or her hand. If target player does not have enough cards, his or her entire hand is discarded.

cards.name: Initiates of the Ebon Hand
cards.text: {1}: Add {B}. If this ability has been activated four or more times this turn, sacrifice Initiates of the Ebon Hand at the beginning of the next end step.
cards.flavor:
"We are no longer Nature's children, but her masters . . . ."
—Oath of the Ebon Hand

rulings.text: Mana which "changes color" as it goes through the Hand forgets its original source because the old mana gets used up and new mana gets generated.

cards.originalText: {1}: Add {B} to your mana pool. Play this ability as an interrupt. If more than {3} is spent in this way during one turn, bury Initiates of the Ebon Hand at end of turn.

cards.name: Initiates of the Ebon Hand
cards.text: {1}: Add {B}. If this ability has been activated four or more times this turn, sacrifice Initiates of the Ebon Hand at the beginning of the next end step.
cards.flavor:
"Many Initiates sacrificed a hand to become full members of the Order."
—Sarpadian Empires, vol. II

rulings.text: Mana which "changes color" as it goes through the Hand forgets its original source because the old mana gets used up and new mana gets generated.

cards.originalText: {1}: Add {B} to your mana pool. Play this ability as an interrupt. If more than {3} is spent in this way during one turn, bury Initiates of the Ebon Hand at end of turn.

cards.name: Initiates of the Ebon Hand
cards.text: {1}: Add {B}. If this ability has been activated four or more times this turn, sacrifice Initiates of the Ebon Hand at the beginning of the next end step.
cards.flavor: Ebon leaders soon realized that non-human races often had special talents that could be exploited.

rulings.text: Mana which "changes color" as it goes through the Hand forgets its original source because the old mana gets used up and new mana gets generated.

cards.originalText: {1}: Add {B} to your mana pool. Play this ability as an interrupt. If more than {3} is spent in this way during one turn, bury Initiates of the Ebon Hand at end of turn.

cards.name: Mindstab Thrull
cards.text: Whenever Mindstab Thrull attacks and isn't blocked, you may sacrifice it. If you do, defending player discards three cards.

rulings.text: The defending player gets to choose which cards they discard.

An ability that triggers when something "attacks and isn't blocked" triggers in the declare blockers step after blockers are declared if (1) that creature is attacking and (2) no creatures are declared to block it. It will trigger even if that creature was put onto the battlefield attacking rather than having been declared as an attacker in the declare attackers step.

cards.originalText: If Mindstab Thrull attacks and is not blocked, you may sacrifice it to force the player it attacked to discard three cards. If you do so, it deals no damage during combat this turn. If that player does not have enough cards, his or her entire hand is discarded.

cards.name: Mindstab Thrull
cards.text: Whenever Mindstab Thrull attacks and isn't blocked, you may sacrifice it. If you do, defending player discards three cards.

rulings.text: The defending player gets to choose which cards they discard.

It will trigger even if that creature was put onto the battlefield attacking rather than having been declared as an attacker in the declare attackers step.

cards.originalText: If Mindstab Thrull attacks and is not blocked, you may sacrifice it to force the player it attacked to discard three cards. If you do so, it deals no damage during combat this turn. If that player does not have enough cards, his or her entire hand is discarded.

cards.text: Whenever Mindstab Thrull attacks and isn't blocked, you may sacrifice it. If you do, defending player discards three cards.

rulings.text: The defending player gets to choose which cards they discard.

An ability that triggers when something "attacks and isn't blocked" triggers in the declare blockers step after blockers are declared if (1) that creature is attacking and (2) no creatures are declared to block it. It will trigger even if that creature was put onto the battlefield attacking rather than having been declared as an attacker in the declare attackers step.

cards.originalText: If Mindstab Thrull attacks and is not blocked, you may sacrifice it to force the player it attacked to discard three cards. If you do so, it deals no damage during combat this turn. If that player does not have enough cards, his or her entire hand is discarded.

cards.name: Necrite
cards.text: Whenever Necrite attacks and isn't blocked, you may sacrifice it. If you do, destroy target creature defending player controls. It can't be regenerated.
cards.flavor: "Ever see a wall drop dead of fright, kid? It ain't pretty." —Cpl. Dobbs

rulings.text: An ability that triggers when something "attacks and isn't blocked" triggers in the declare blockers step after blockers are declared if (1) that creature is attacking and (2) no creatures are declared to block it. It will trigger even if that creature was put onto the battlefield attacking rather than having been declared as an attacker in the declare attackers step.

cards.originalText: If Necrite attacks and is not blocked, you may sacrifice it to bury a target creature controlled by the player Necrite attacked this turn. If you do so, Necrite deals no damage during combat this turn.

cards.name: Necrite
cards.text: Whenever Necrite attacks and isn't blocked, you may sacrifice it. If you do, destroy target creature defending player controls. It can't be regenerated.
cards.flavor: Necrites killed Jherana Rure, ending the counter-insurgency.

rulings.text: An ability that triggers when something "attacks and isn't blocked" triggers in the declare blockers step after blockers are declared if (1) that creature is attacking and (2) no creatures are declared to block it. It will trigger even if that creature was put onto the battlefield attacking rather than having been declared as an attacker in the declare attackers step.

cards.originalText: If Necrite attacks and is not blocked, you may sacrifice it to bury a target creature controlled by the player Necrite attacked this turn. If you do so, Necrite deals no damage during combat this turn.

cards.name: Necrite
cards.text: Whenever Necrite attacks and isn't blocked, you may sacrifice it. If you do, destroy target creature defending player controls. It can't be regenerated.
cards.flavor: Was it the sight, smell, or aura of the Necrite that killed so effectively?

rulings.text: An ability that triggers when something "attacks and isn't blocked" triggers in the declare blockers step after blockers are declared if (1) that creature is attacking and (2) no creatures are declared to block it. It will trigger even if that creature was put onto the battlefield attacking rather than having been declared as an attacker in the declare attackers step.

cards.originalText: If Necrite attacks and is not blocked, you may sacrifice it to bury a target creature controlled by the player Necrite attacked this turn. If you do so, Necrite deals no damage during combat this turn.

cards.name: Order of the Ebon Hand
cards.text:
Protection from white
{B}: Order of the Ebon Hand gains first strike until end of turn.
{B}{B}: Order of the Ebon Hand gets +1/+0 until end of turn.
cards.flavor:
"There are intriguing similarities between the Order and Icatia's Leitbur religion, suggesting the two had a common origin."
—Sarpadian Empires, vol. VI
cards.originalText:
Protection from white
{B}{B}: +1/+0 until end of turn
{B}: First strike until end of turn

cards.name: Order of the Ebon Hand
cards.text:
Protection from white
{B}: Order of the Ebon Hand gains first strike until end of turn.
{B}{B}: Order of the Ebon Hand gets +1/+0 until end of turn.
cards.flavor: A true follower of Tourach took pride in achievement to the exclusion of other concerns.
cards.originalText:
Protection from white
{B}{B}: +1/+0 until end of turn
{B}: First strike until end of turn

cards.name: Order of the Ebon Hand
cards.text:
Protection from white
{B}: Order of the Ebon Hand gains first strike until end of turn.
{B}{B}: Order of the Ebon Hand gets +1/+0 until end of turn.
cards.flavor: Dedicated to the principles of Tourach, members of the Order of the Ebon Hand demonstrated their devotion with grisly rituals.
cards.originalText:
Protection from white
{B}{B}: +1/+0 until end of turn
{B}: First strike until end of turn

cards.name: Soul Exchange
cards.text:
As an additional cost to cast this spell, exile a creature you control.
Return target creature card from your graveyard to the battlefield. Put a +2/+2 counter on that creature if the exiled creature was a Thrull.

rulings.text: Putting a counter on the creature put onto the battlefield is not a targeted effect and so Protection from Black will not prevent it.
You exile exactly one creature. You can't exile more than one in an attempt to get a larger effect.

cards.originalText: Sacrifice a creature, but remove it from the game instead of putting it in your graveyard. Take a creature from your graveyard and put it directly into play as though it were just summoned. Put a +2/+2 counter on this creature if the creature sacrificed was a Thrull.

cards.name: Thrull Champion
cards.text:
Thrull creatures get +1/+1.
{T}: Gain control of target Thrull for as long as you control Thrull Champion.
cards.flavor:
"Those idiots should never have bred Thrulls for combat!"
—Jherana Rure

rulings.text: Can be used to steal another Thrull Champion.
Gives himself +1/+1.
Unlike many similar creatures, Thrull Champion untaps as normal during your untap step. Whether it's tapped or untapped has no bearing on the control-change effect.

cards.originalText:
All Thrulls get +1/+1.
{T}: Take control of a target Thrull. You lose control of target Thrull if Thrull Champion leaves play or you lose control of Thrull Champion.

cards.name: Thrull Retainer
cards.text:
Enchant creature
Enchanted creature gets +1/+1.
Sacrifice Thrull Retainer: Regenerate enchanted creature.
cards.flavor:
"Until the Rebellion, Thrulls served their masters faithfully—even at the cost of their own lives."
—Sarpadian Empires, vol. II

rulings.text: This leaves the battlefield when you activate its activated ability, but the enchanted creature won't be regenerated until the ability resolves. In the intervening time, the creature will no longer have the bonus that this had been giving it. This may cause the creature to be destroyed before the regeneration shield is created.

cards.originalText:
Target creature gets +1/+1.
Sacrifice Thrull Retainer to regenerate the creature it enchants.

cards.name: Thrull Wizard
cards.text: {1}{B}: Counter target black spell unless that spell's controller pays {B} or {3}.
cards.flavor:
"In crafting intelligent Thrulls to assist in sacrifices, Sahr inadvertantly set the stage for the Thrull Rebellion."
—Sarpadian Empires, vol. II

rulings.text: You can use this ability multiple times on one spell to force your opponent to use more than one mana to prevent the spell from being countered. You can even use this ability, let them pay, then use this ability repeatedly.

cards.originalText: {1}{B}: Counters a target black spell if caster of target spell does not pay an additional {B} or {3}. Play this ability as an interrupt.

cards.name: Tourach's Chant
cards.text:
At the beginning of your upkeep, sacrifice Tourach's Chant unless you pay {B}.
Whenever a player puts a Forest onto the battlefield, Tourach's Chant deals 3 damage to that player unless they put a -1/-1 counter on a creature they control.

rulings.text: Only checks the type of the land as it is put onto the battlefield. If the land gets changed after it enters the battlefield (even by a continuous effect), the Chant causes no additional effect.

cards.originalText:
During your upkeep, pay {B} or bury Tourach's Chant.
Whenever a player puts a forest into play, Tourach's Chant deals 3 damage to him or her unless that player puts a -1/-1 counter on a target creature he or she controls.

cards.name: Tourach's Gate
cards.text:
Enchant land you control
Sacrifice a Thrull: Put three time counters on Tourach's Gate.
At the beginning of your upkeep, remove a time counter from Tourach's Gate. If there are no time counters on Tourach's Gate, sacrifice it.
Tap enchanted land: Attacking creatures you control get +2/-1 until end of turn. Activate this ability only if enchanted land is untapped.
cards.originalText:
Can only be played on a target land you control. Sacrifice a Thrull to put three time counters on Tourach's Gate. During your upkeep, remove a time counter from Tourach's Gate. If there are no time counters on Tourach's Gate, bury it.
{0}: Tap land Tourach's Gate enchants. All attacking creatures you control get +2/-1 until end of turn.

cards.name: Deep Spawn
cards.text:
Trample
At the beginning of your upkeep, sacrifice Deep Spawn unless you put the top two cards of your library into your graveyard.
{U}: Deep Spawn gains shroud until end of turn and doesn't untap during your next untap step. Tap Deep Spawn. (A creature with shroud can't be the target of spells or abilities.)
cards.originalText:
Trample
During your upkeep, take two cards from the top of your library and put them in your graveyard, or destroy Deep Spawn.
{U}: Deep Spawn may not be the target of spells or effects until end of turn and does not untap as normal during your next untap phase. If Deep Spawn is untapped, tap it.

cards.name: High Tide
cards.text: Until end of turn, whenever a player taps an Island for mana, that player adds an additional {U}.
cards.flavor:
"May Svyelun and her tides favor you."
—Traditional Merfolk blessing

rulings.text: The delayed triggered ability triggers and produces {U} any time a land with the land-type Island is tapped for mana, even if that land has other types or the mana for which it was tapped is another color. For example, if you tap a Breeding Pool for {G}, High Tide will give you an extra {U}.
The effect applies even if the Island in question entered the battlefield after High Tide resolved.

cards.originalText: Until end of turn, all islands produce an additional {U} when tapped for mana.

cards.name: High Tide
cards.text: Until end of turn, whenever a player taps an Island for mana, that player adds an additional {U}.
cards.flavor:

—General Khurzog

cards.name: Homarid
cards.text:
Homarid enters the battlefield with a tide counter on it.
At the beginning of your upkeep, put a tide counter on Homarid.
As long as there is exactly one tide counter on Homarid, it gets -1/-1.
As long as there are exactly three tide counters on Homarid, it gets +1/+1.
Whenever there are four or more tide counters on Homarid, remove all tide counters from it.
cards.originalText: Put a tide counter on Homarid when it is brought into play and during your upkeep. If there is one tide counter on Homarid, it gets -1/-1. If there are three tide counters on Homarid, it gets +1/+1. When there are four tide counters on Homarid, remove them all.

cards.name: Homarid Shaman
cards.text: {U}: Tap target green creature.
cards.flavor:
"The ground grew swampy; hooves and claws sank into the marshy earth. Snarls of rage and bleats of despair echoed through the trees as the waters grew higher and higher."
—Kyliki of Havenwood,
"Havenwood Remembered"
cards.originalText: {U}: Tap a target green creature.
